unnormalised: Okay guys, let's talk online shopping! Seriously, who doesn't love a good online haul, right? Especially when you can snag amazing deals from the comfort of your own home in your PJs. But lately, I've been noticing some interesting trends, and thought I'd share my 2 cents.
normalised: Okay guys, let us talk online shopping! Seriously, who does not love a good online haul, right? Especially when you can snag amazing deals from the comfort of your own home in your P-Jays. But lately, I have been noticing some interesting trends, and thought I would share my two cents.

unnormalised: First off, the crazy discounts are getting even crazier! Like, I saw a dress listed for ₹199 after a "massive" 80% off. I mean, at that price, even if it falls apart after 2 washes, it's still worth it, no? Jokes aside, the competition is fierce, and everyone is trying to undercut each other. And it seems like the return policies keep getting more customer-friendly, too. Some sites are even offering 30-day no-questions-asked returns. Wah, what a time to be alive!

I mean, at that price, even if it falls apart after two washes, it is still worth it, no? Jokes aside, the competition is fierce, and everyone is trying to undercut each other. And it seems like the return policies keep getting more customer-friendly, too. Some sites are even offering thirty day no-questions-asked returns. Wah, what a time to be alive!

unnormalised: And then there’s the whole UPI thing. Gone are the days of net banking and OTPs. Now it's just a quick scan, enter your pin, and BAM! Payment done in like, 5 seconds. I’ve noticed that ~70% of my payments are via UPI now! So convenient for even small purchases like Rs. 50 or Rs. 100.
normalised: And then there is the whole U-P-I thing. Gone are the days of net banking and O-T-P-s. Now it is just a quick scan, enter your pin, and B-A-M! Payment done in like, five seconds. I have noticed that approximately seventy percent of my payments are via U-P-I now! So convenient for even small purchases like rupees fifty or rupees one hundred.

unnormalised: Another thing: the rise of smaller, niche e-commerce sites. You know, the ones that specialize in things like artisanal crafts or organic skincare. I bought a gorgeous handloom saree from one of these for Rs. 2500 and the quality was AMAZING. Supporting local businesses while getting something unique? Yes, please! But gotta be careful about trusting these sites.

I bought a gorgeous handloom saree from one of these for rupees two thousand and five hundred and the quality was A-M-A-Z-I-N-G. Supporting local businesses while getting something unique? Yes, please! But gotta be careful about trusting these sites.

unnormalised: But here's where it gets a little tricky. I've noticed some websites being sneaky with their prices. Like, they'll bump up the "shipping charges" to like, Rs. 99 after luring you in with a cheap product. Or they will show you one price then sneakily add tax + convenience fee and other surcharges which were hidden initially. Always double-check before hitting that "Pay Now" button, alright? Make sure you read the fine print especially concerning return policies before you add the product in cart, as the final price might be Rs. 50 or even Rs. 100 more!

unnormalised: And don’t even get me started on the flash sales! Sites launching stuff like, "Buy 1 Get 1 Free for the next 2 hours only!". It's a total impulse-buying trap, but man, sometimes you just can’t resist, no? Especially when the items are up to 90% off.

unnormalised: So yeah, that's my take on the current e-commerce scene in India. It’s a wild ride, full of amazing deals and potential pitfalls. Just remember to shop smart, compare prices, read reviews, and always double-check that final amount before you click confirm! Happy shopping, folks and avoid getting a hole in your pocket.
